title: 111_hr230
content: The Act may be cited as the "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" and includes provisions for affordable refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The "Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009" mandates the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages on single-family housing. The Director of the Federal Housing Finance Agency will establish policies and procedures for this program. If a lender offers a mortgage for purchase, the enterprise will determine if it meets the requirements for qualified mortgages. The Director will determine if a mortgage qualifies for purchase under the Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009. If it meets the requirements for a qualified mortgage, the enterprise will commit to purchasing it. Lenders can receive advance commitments for qualified mortgages. The Housing Opportunity and Mortgage Equity Act of 2009 allows lenders to receive advance commitments for qualified mortgages, which can be either qualified refinancing mortgages or qualified new mortgages. Qualified refinancing mortgages must meet specific requirements, including being for single-family housing and the mortgagor occupying the property as their principal residence. The mortgage must be for single-family housing, with the mortgagor occupying the property as their principal residence. The loan amount must be used to pay off existing indebtedness on the same property. The qualified refinancing mortgage must be used to pay off an existing first mortgage on the same property, originated on or before January 1, 2008. The new mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term of 30 to 40 years. The refinancing mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term of 30 to 40 years. Underwriting standards set by the Director must be met, and all prepayment penalties and fees related to default or delinquency on the original mortgage must be waived. The qualified new mortgage must have a fixed interest rate not exceeding 4.0% annually and a term of 30 to 40 years. All penalties for prepayment or refinancing of the underlying mortgage, as well as fees and penalties related to default or delinquency, must be waived. The principal loan amount secured by the mortgage must be used to purchase the property subject to the qualified new mortgage. Exceptions to underwriting standards are allowed for enterprises to conform to established standards for purchasing and securitizing qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. The enterprise must adhere to underwriting standards to purchase and securitize qualified refinancing mortgages and new mortgages. Each enterprise is required to set aside qualified mortgages and issue securities based on them, subject to approval by the Secretary of the Treasury. Securities can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates. Securities issued by an enterprise under this subsection, based on qualified mortgages, can be in the form of debt obligations or trust certificates. The terms of these securities, including maturities and interest rates, are determined by the enterprise with approval from the Secretary of the Treasury. These securities are considered exempt securities, similar to those guaranteed by the United States, and payments are made on the principal and interest of the mortgages set aside. Securities issued under this subsection are considered exempt securities, similar to those guaranteed by the United States. Mortgages set aside must ensure timely principal and interest payments on the securities. The securities are not guaranteed by the United States and do not constitute a debt or obligation of the United States. Each enterprise must include language in securities issued under this subsection stating that they are not guaranteed by the United States and do not constitute a debt of the United States. The Federal Reserve will establish a credit facility to provide credit to enterprises at interest rates comparable to Treasury securities. The Federal Reserve System will provide credit to enterprises at interest rates similar to Treasury securities, with comparable terms. The enterprises are not required to purchase mortgages after December 31, 2010. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines the Director as the head of the Federal Housing Finance Agency, the Enterprise as the Federal National Mortgage Association and the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation, and the Secretary as the head of the Treasury.
